articles.headline: High-Tech Japan Running Out of Engineers
articles.snippet: Engineering skill made Japan an economic superpower, but its young people are now choosing other careers.
articles.abstract: Engineering skill made Japan an economic superpower, but its young people are now choosing other careers.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  Japan is running out of engineers.

articles.headline: Obama Says Bush and McCain Are ‘Fear Mongering’ in Attacks
articles.snippet: Senator Barack Obama responded to attacks on his foreign policy and tried to turn the tables on his critics.
articles.abstract: Senator Barack Obama responded to attacks on his foreign policy and tried to turn the tables on his critics.
articles.lead_paragraph: WATERTOWN, S.D.  Senator Barack Obama responded sharply on Friday to attacks on his foreign policy, linking President Bush and Senator John McCain as partners in “the failed policies” of the past seven years and criticizing them for “hypocrisy, fear peddling, fear mongering.”

articles.headline: This July 4, Fewer Bombs May Burst in Air
articles.snippet: An explosion that destroyed 20 fireworks warehouses in China three months ago will probably mean dimmer night skies on the Fourth of July in the United States.
articles.abstract: An explosion that destroyed 20 fireworks warehouses in China three months ago will probably mean dimmer night skies on the Fourth of July in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: An explosion that destroyed 20 fireworks warehouses in China three months ago will probably dim night skies in the United States this Fourth of July.

articles.headline: Congressional Pressure Prevails as U.S. Halts Filling of Oil Reserve
articles.snippet: An Energy Department announcement that it would temporarily suspend a program to fill the nation’s strategic oil stocks failed to break the rally in oil prices, which hit another record Friday.
articles.abstract: An Energy Department announcement that it would temporarily suspend a program to fill the nation’s strategic oil stocks failed to break the rally in oil prices, which hit another record Friday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bowing to pressure from Congress, the Energy Department said Friday that it would temporarily suspend a program to fill the nation’s strategic oil stocks.

articles.headline: Famine Looms as Wars Rend Horn of Africa
articles.snippet: Villagers say Somalis are dying of hunger and thirst amid soaring food prices, skimpy rainfall and rising violence.
articles.abstract: Villagers say Somalis are dying of hunger and thirst amid soaring food prices, skimpy rainfall and rising violence.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAGAARI, Somalia — The global food crisis has arrived at Safia Ali’s hut.

articles.headline: New Tack on Straying Parolees Offers a Hand Instead of Cuffs
articles.snippet: Several states are focusing on rehabilitating offenders instead of punishing them for parole violations.
articles.abstract: Several states are focusing on rehabilitating offenders instead of punishing them for parole violations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WICHITA, Kan.  Since his release in January after serving time for a 2006 theft conviction, Lonnie Kemp has violated his parole conditions several times, getting drunk and kicked out of a halfway house and showing traces of marijuana in urine tests. If this were a few years ago, he almost certainly would be back in prison.

articles.headline: Passions Run High on Indexing
articles.snippet: An academic debate on a financial product called fundamentally weighted indexes turned out to be quite the snake pit.
articles.abstract: An academic debate on a financial product called fundamentally weighted indexes turned out to be quite the snake pit.
articles.lead_paragraph: Did you see the latest issue of The Financial Analysts Journal?

articles.headline: U.S. Planning Big New Prison in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: Officials are scaling back plans to shift prisoners into Afghan custody in a stark acknowledgment that the U.S. is likely to hold prisoners overseas for years.
articles.abstract: Officials are scaling back plans to shift prisoners into Afghan custody in a stark acknowledgment that the U.S. is likely to hold prisoners overseas for years.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon is moving forward with plans to build a new, 40-acre detention complex on the main American military base in Afghanistan, officials said, in a stark acknowledgment that the United States is likely to continue to hold prisoners overseas for years to come.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Tim Golden

articles.headline: Five Basics for Building a Solid Financial Future
articles.snippet: A new Times columnist offers guidance for making financial decisions, when making good ones is more critical than ever.
articles.abstract: A new Times columnist offers guidance for making financial decisions, when making good ones is more critical than ever.
articles.lead_paragraph: The stark truth about managing our money these days is that we are mostly on our own.

articles.headline: Doctors Say ‘I’m Sorry’ Before ‘See You in Court’
articles.snippet: Some prominent medical centers are offering apologies and compensation to try to dilute patients’ anger.
articles.abstract: Some prominent medical centers are offering apologies and compensation to try to dilute patients’ anger.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  In 40 years as a highly regarded cancer surgeon, Dr. Tapas K. Das Gupta had never made a mistake like this.

articles.headline: Hezbollah Ignites a Sectarian Fuse in Lebanon
articles.snippet: After almost a week of street battles, long-simmering Sunni-Shiite tensions have sharply worsened, in an ominous echo of the civil conflict in Iraq.
articles.abstract: After almost a week of street battles, long-simmering Sunni-Shiite tensions have sharply worsened, in an ominous echo of the civil conflict in Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: MENIEH, Lebanon  For two and a half days, Hussein al-Haj Obaid lay on the floor of a darkened warehouse in west Beirut, blindfolded and terrified. Militiamen loyal to Hezbollah had kidnapped him at a checkpoint after killing his nephew right in front of him.
articles.byline: By Robert F. Worth and Nada Bakri

articles.headline: What a Deal: Trash for Treasuries
articles.snippet: Part of the Federal Reserve’s plan to keep Wall Street solvent — letting banks trade hard-to-sell securities for cash — could force the taxpayers to cover losses.
articles.abstract: Part of the Federal Reserve’s plan to keep Wall Street solvent — letting banks trade hard-to-sell securities for cash — could force the taxpayers to cover losses.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAVING the nation’s financial system from reckless banks and brokerage firms is an enormous job, heaven knows. But somebody’s got to do it, so the Federal Reserve Board, with its taxpayer-funded balance sheet, stepped in.

articles.headline: As Prices Rise, Crime Tipsters Work Overtime
articles.snippet: Another rising economic indicator: the number of tips to the police from people hoping to collect reward money.
articles.abstract: Another rising economic indicator: the number of tips to the police from people hoping to collect reward money.
articles.lead_paragraph: To gas prices, foreclosure rates and the cost of rice, add this rising economic indicator: the number of tips to the police from people hoping to collect reward money.
articles.byline: By Shaila Dewan and Brenda Goodman

articles.headline: An E-Commerce Empire, From Porn to Puppies
articles.snippet: Rooted in the sexual entertainment industry, the empire of Richard J. Gordon, who played a significant role in the birth of electronic commerce, also reaches more far-flung places.
articles.abstract: Rooted in the sexual entertainment industry, the empire of Richard J. Gordon, who played a significant role in the birth of electronic commerce, also reaches more far-flung places.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIBUTES on the Web site of Richard J. Gordon‘s company strike all of the uplifting chords one would expect of a digital maverick. He is described as a “trailblazing businessman” who is “operating in the front ranks of those transforming the Internet into the global marketplace of the future.”

articles.headline: The Story of Obama, Written by Obama
articles.snippet: Barack Obama has packaged his life story into two hugely successful books that have made him a best-selling millionaire.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama has packaged his life story into two hugely successful books that have made him a best-selling millionaire.
articles.lead_paragraph: Barack Obama was a first-time author and rookie politician embarking upon his first run for public office. Hermene Hartman was the publisher of N’Digo, a magazine in Chicago aimed at upscale black readers. As Ms. Hartman tells it, she got a call from Mr. Obama in the fall of 1995 saying he wanted to come and talk. He wanted her to read his newly published memoir.

articles.headline: Chinese Flee Flood Threat From Quake
articles.snippet: Thousands of earthquake survivors fled camps and villages after warnings that lakes and rivers were getting close to overflowing.
articles.abstract: Thousands of earthquake survivors fled camps and villages after warnings that lakes and rivers were getting close to overflowing.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHENGDU, China  Thousands of earthquake survivors fled tent camps and villages across the ravaged landscape of southwestern China on Saturday after the government warned that several lakes and rivers were getting dangerously close to overflowing because landslides have blocked water flow.

articles.headline: World’s Poor Pay Price as Crop Research Is Cut
articles.snippet: Agricultural research is reduced even as the growth of the global food supply slows and the population increases.
articles.abstract: Agricultural research is reduced even as the growth of the global food supply slows and the population increases.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS BAÑOS, Philippines  The brown plant hopper, an insect no bigger than a gnat, is multiplying by the billions and chewing through rice paddies in East Asia, threatening the diets of many poor people.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Andrew Martin

articles.headline: The True Story of a Script, Big Dreams and Vanishing Private Equity
articles.snippet: A would-be filmmaker is left in the lurch by nervous lenders, and his tale is becoming a common one as private money has become harder to obtain in Hollywood.
articles.abstract: A would-be filmmaker is left in the lurch by nervous lenders, and his tale is becoming a common one as private money has become harder to obtain in Hollywood.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Last September, when Sanjay Sanghoee set about turning his first novel into a Hollywood movie, the budding filmmaker had his pick of investors.

articles.headline: Online Search Ads Faring Better Than Expensive Displays
articles.snippet: While search advertising remains strong, there are signs that the growth in online advertising — particularly in more elaborate display ads — is slowing.
articles.abstract: While search advertising remains strong, there are signs that the growth in online advertising — particularly in more elaborate display ads — is slowing.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the past few years, Web publishers have made a big bet on booming online advertising revenues. But the economic slowdown may be throwing a wrench into those plans.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Miguel Helft

articles.headline: McCain to Rely on Party Money Against Obama
articles.snippet: John McCain, who suffered a blow as a key fund-raiser resigned, is leaning on the Republican Party as Barack Obama turns again to his fund-raising juggernaut.
articles.abstract: John McCain, who suffered a blow as a key fund-raiser resigned, is leaning on the Republican Party as Barack Obama turns again to his fund-raising juggernaut.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pivoting toward the general election, Senator Barack Obama is turning again to his history-making fund-raising machine, which helped to anoint him as a contender against Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and then became a potent weapon in their battle for the Democratic nomination.
articles.byline: By Michael Luo and Mike McIntire

articles.headline: Gender Issue Lives On as Clinton’s Bid Wanes
articles.snippet: The senator’s waning bid brings with it a reckoning about what it represents: an incomplete triumph or a sad reminder of why few women run for high office.
articles.abstract: The senator’s waning bid brings with it a reckoning about what it represents: an incomplete triumph or a sad reminder of why few women run for high office.
articles.lead_paragraph: With each passing day, it seems a little less likely that the next president of the United States will wear a skirt  or a cheerful, no-nonsense pantsuit.

articles.headline: Banks’ Terms Imperil Deal to Buy Out Bell Canada
articles.snippet: The $51.8 billion takeover of Bell Canada, the largest leveraged buyout ever proposed, is the latest buyout to run into trouble since the credit market began tightening.
articles.abstract: The $51.8 billion takeover of Bell Canada, the largest leveraged buyout ever proposed, is the latest buyout to run into trouble since the credit market began tightening.
articles.lead_paragraph: The $51.8 billion takeover of Bell Canada, the largest leveraged buyout ever proposed, appeared to be in trouble over the weekend as the Wall Street banks that committed to finance the deal sought to renegotiate the lending terms, people on both sides of the transaction said on Sunday.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Geeks Crash a House of Fashion
articles.snippet: Condé Nast Publications, like other big media companies, is making acquisitions, but with a different strategy: to find impresarios, remain patient and build vital brands.
articles.abstract: Condé Nast Publications, like other big media companies, is making acquisitions, but with a different strategy: to find impresarios, remain patient and build vital brands.
articles.lead_paragraph: Of all the dot-com publishing franchises, Wired seemed the most likely to end up as road kill on a superhighway it helped create.

articles.headline: For an All-Organic Formula, Baby, That’s Sweet
articles.snippet: A popular organic infant formula is sweetened with cane sugar, which babies may prefer but pediatricians do not.
articles.abstract: A popular organic infant formula is sweetened with cane sugar, which babies may prefer but pediatricians do not.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amy Chase started feeding Similac Organic infant formula to her second son, Amos, as soon as he was born in November 2006.

articles.headline: Pursuit of Yahoo Shows Microsoft Needs a Franchise
articles.snippet: Fighting Google, Microsoft has approached Yahoo with a narrower aim: a collaboration on Internet advertising.
articles.abstract: Fighting Google, Microsoft has approached Yahoo with a narrower aim: a collaboration on Internet advertising.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two weeks after walking away from takeover talks with Yahoo, Microsoft made clear on Sunday that it still needed to create an Internet powerhouse that could rival Google  and that its interest in Yahoo had not waned.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Steve Lohr

articles.headline: At Sci Fi Channel, the Universe Is Expanding and the Future Is Now
articles.snippet: To expand its audience, the channel is stretching the definition of science fiction to include superheroes, Indiana Jones and even the baseball film “Field of Dreams.”
articles.abstract: To expand its audience, the channel is stretching the definition of science fiction to include superheroes, Indiana Jones and even the baseball film “Field of Dreams.”
articles.lead_paragraph: The letters still keep coming to the Rockefeller Center offices of the Sci Fi Channel. Please, they all say, pick up “Jericho,” the science fiction show with a small but passionate following that was canceled in March by CBS, for a third season.

articles.headline: In Rubble, Couple Clung to Each Other, and to Life
articles.snippet: A tale of survival in China is also a tale of a rekindled love for two people who might have died had they been trapped alone.
articles.abstract: A tale of survival in China is also a tale of a rekindled love for two people who might have died had they been trapped alone.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHIFANG, China  At the moment of greatest despair, Wang Zhijun tried to kill himself by twisting his neck against the debris.
